>Quoth Chappell, Simon P:
> [ whether NullPtrExc is a good thing to throw (v. IllegalArgExc) ]
>> You are correct, but I actually meant that at runtime,
>> my code does not know why your code threw an NPE.
>
>Jumping in here on a point I haven't really understood in all this
>discussion:
>
>I can see that it is at least somewhat useful for the human
>troubleshooter reading the stack trace to be able to see quickly
>that the problem is an invalid argument, and not a surprising null
>somewhere in the guts of the method; this may well speed up the
>troubleshooting, and makes an argument for throwing IllegalArgExc
>as a matter of style.
>
>But why would the calling code care? For example, why would it
>react differently to an IllegalArgExc than to any random
>RuntimeException?

Good question. I hope that I can provide a good answer. The reason why my code would care about the type of exception raised by the code that I have called is that there are some exceptions that are non-terminal and that when received, my code will try to do something about it. Let's try an example:

An IllegalArgumentException means that I have messed up.

A JDBC Connection exception might mean that the database is down, and that if my code is patient and retries in a few seconds, then everything may be connected again. (This is not unusual ... I have found allowing for a number of retries to be a good thing when working with both database connections and also messaging systems)

A NullPointerException means nothing to anybody's code. Did I pass a Null value, or did the code that I called mess up or did it call some other code and that messed up? Who knows!?

And this is why my code cares about the exception that comes back. I can make programatic decisions based upon the exception that is returned, if the exception that is returned is meaningfull.

Hope this helps.

Simon
